Award.AwardTitle: Integrating Experiments With Observations at Oldoinyo Lengai; Insights Into Alkalic Magmatic Processes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The formation and eruption of magma from the world's only carbonatite volcano, Ol Doinyo Lengai in Tanzania, continues to amaze and perplex earth scientists. The magma originates as mantle derived but the processes leading to its unique, low temperature lava remain undefined. What is the process that forms it? This project will undertake experiments and analyses of lavas from this volcano to gain fundamental insight into the general processes by which Earth's magmas change composition and ultimately erupt.

Previous workers have hypothesized that these magmas reflect an immiscibility reaction that occurs to ultimately form two magmas, one silicate and one carbonatite. These researchers will perform the new technique of Fe isotope ratio analyses along with laboratory experiments at high pressure and temperature to assess this hypothesis. Specifically, they will perform experiments to measure the Fe isotopic fractionation factor between 2 coexisting immiscible melts. Furthermore, they will perform thermal gradient experiments to assess the possible role of this process on forming the compositional evolution sequence observed in erupted rocks. The team will use new tomographic X-ray imaging techniques to assess the melt distribution in these experiments to help constrain observed electromagnetic signatures around Ol'doinyo Lengai. Use of U-series disequilibria techniques will allow us to constrain the timing and processes of magma formation with the thermal gradient experiment results used to assess a new model for disequilibria generation. The information obtained will help to understand the hazards associated with continental rift volcanism.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Carbonatite is an igneous rock formed from a magma made of a carbonate not silicate like most magma on Earth. While it is known to be derived from the Earth’s mantle, how it forms is poorly understood. Found throughout Earth history, carbonatites are only currently observed to erupt from one volcano, Ol Doinyo Lengai (ODL) in Tanzania. This project involved 3 separate tasks aimed at understanding the origin of carbonatite and its relationship to coexisting silicate magmas. We performed laboratory experiments and isotopic analyses of ODL rocks.   

 

The laboratory experiments provided novel insight into the process of carbonatite formation. In temperature gradient experiments involving a hydrous sodium carbonate melt placed in a silicate crystal mush, we find that a continuum of changing melt compositions can exist from high temperature silicate melts at 1000°C down to a hydrous sodium carbonate at temperatures <400°C.  These experiments provide a new explanation for how carbonatite forms implying that in an upper crustal magma chamber, naturally under a thermal gradient, carbonatite can form and buoyantly rise, resulting in the effusion of low viscosity magma at <500°C. The corresponding analytical work provides support for this percolation model. Iron and uranium isotopes show offsets between the carbonatite and silicate magmas, explained as isotopic partitioning between rising magma and crystals in the magma chamber mush.  Finally, Uranium series disquilibria data put strict timing constraints on the process, consistent with process of partitioning between the ascending melt and the magma chamber mush.
